com.flipkart.iris.bufferqueue
Interface BufferQueue

All Known Implementing Classes:
MappedBufferQueue
public interface BufferQueue

An API for a queue that is intended to be used as a local buffer for data before it is sent to remote systems. Publishing and consumption must be completely thread-safe. Each entry in a BufferQueue is represented by a BufferQueueEntry. Enqueuing/publishing data to the queue is a 3-step process: 1. "Claim" a new entry using the method next() 2. Write the data to the returned BufferQueueEntry using any method that it offers 3. Mark the entry as published by calling BufferQueueEntry.markPublished() Alternatively, calling publish(byte[] data) will internally do all these steps automatically. Multiple next()/publish(byte[] data) calls could be happening in parallel and entries must be made available for consumption in the order in which they were claimed. Dequeueing/consuming data from the queue is also a 3-step process: 1. Get the next entry to be consumed from the queue by calling consume() 2. Read and consume the data from the returned BufferQueueEntry 3. Mark the entry as consumed by calling BufferQueueEntry.markConsumed() Consumption using the above process will be ordered -- messages will be consumed in the same order in which they were claimed/published. Until a message is marked as consumed, the next message will not be returned. Thus it does not make sense to consume in parallel -- the same entry will be delivered to multiple queues. There is also a batch consume API in the form of the method consume(int n) that allows consumption of multiple entries (up to n) at the same time. This can also be used to parallelize consumption -- get a batch of entries and then hand them off to a separate set of worker threads to process. Please note that this would imply that entries would be processed out-of-order.

See Also:
BufferQueueEntry

Method Detail

next

com.google.common.base.Optional<BufferQueueEntry> next()
Claim the next entry in the buffer queue. Important: The publisher **must** call BufferQueueEntry.markPublished() on the returned BufferQueueEntry, otherwise no consumer will be able to move past this point. BufferQueueEntry.markPublished() **must** be called even if writing data to the buffer failed. It is recommended that this method be called in a finally block; for example: BufferQueueEntry entry = bufferQueue.next(); try { // entry.set(data); } finally { entry.markPublished(); }

Returns:
The claimed entry. The reference will be absent in the Optional if claiming failed (may happen if the buffer is full, for example).
See Also:
BufferQueueEntry.markPublished()

publish

boolean publish(byte[] data)
                throws BufferOverflowException
A higher level helper method to do all the 3-steps of publishing to the BufferQueue in a single method call. This claims a new entry, writes data to the entry and then marks it as published.

Parameters:
data - The data to publish as an entry.
Returns:
Throws:
BufferOverflowException - If the given data does not fit in a single entry.
See Also:
next()

consume

com.google.common.base.Optional<BufferQueueEntry> consume()
Return the next consumable entry from the BufferQueue. Note that until the returned entry is marked as consumed, the same entry will be returned for each call, even if different threads make the call. Thus consumers **must** call BufferQueueEntry.markConsumed() on the returned BufferQueueEntry. It is recommended that this method be called in a finally block; for example: BufferQueueEntry entry = bufferQueue.consume(); try { // consume the data from entry } finally { entry.markConsumed(); }

Returns:
The consumable BufferQueueEntry, null if no consumable entries are currently available or if the next entry is corrupted for any unknown reason.
See Also:
BufferQueueEntry.markConsumed()

consume

List<BufferQueueEntry> consume(int n)
Return the next (up to) n consumable entries from the BufferQueue. Less than n entries (including zero entries) may be returned based on how many entries are currently available. The same set of contracts as specified in consume() apply to this method as well. The returned messages may be marked as consumed out of order. This allows the consumer to parallelize consumption of the messages (over a thread-pool, for example).

Parameters:
n - The number of entries to return.
Returns:
A list of up to n entries.
See Also:
consume()

maxDataLength

int maxDataLength()
BufferQueue implementations may have a max size of data that they accept. Attempting to data with sizes greater than this will result in a BufferOverflowException.

Returns:
The maximum length of data this BufferQueue can accomodate.

capacity

long capacity()
BufferQueue implementations may have a upper limit on the number of unconsumed messages they will hold. This limit is referred to as its capacity.

Returns:
The max number of unconsumed messages this BufferQueue will hold.

size

long size()
Returns the number of unconsumed entries that this BufferQueue currently holds. This number may be returned on a "best-effort" basis and may only be indicative instead of being accurate. This happens mainly because there may be claimed but as yet unpublished entries as well as entries that have been marked as consumed out of order (when using bulk consumption).

Returns:
The current -- approximate -- size of the queue.

isFull

boolean isFull()
Check if the BufferQueue is "full" that is if it has any more capacity to accept newer entries before any more entries are consumed. For certain implementations of BufferQueue it may be more efficient to call this method than call figure this out by calling capacity() and size().

Returns:
true if the BufferQueue is full, false otherwise
See Also:
capacity()

isEmpty

boolean isEmpty()
Check if the BufferQueue has any consumable entries. This may be an approximation and it is possible that even if this returns true there are no consumable entries or vice versa. For certain implementations of BufferQueue it may be more efficient to call this method than call figure this out by calling size().

Returns:
true if the BufferQueue is empty, false otherwise
See Also:
size()
